abstract.p: Personal Shopper column on shelving units that made their debuts during International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York last month; photos (M)

block.p: YOU can't call them book shelves anymore. Books have moved out to make room for CD's, videos, serving dishes, computer disks, office equipment and milk-glass cow heads. The shelving units here made their debuts during the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York last month; they are modular and can expand as the need arises.

YOU can't call them book shelves anymore. Books have moved out to make room for CD's, videos, serving dishes, computer disks, office equipment and milk-glass cow heads. The shelving units here made their debuts during the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York last month; they are modular and can expand as the need arises.

1. The wall-mounted lacquered-wood storage boxes, made in the Netherlands by UMS-Pastoe, look like a cross between medicine cabinets and wall sculpture. Each unit in the line, called Vision, is sold separately, some with drawers, some with shelves, from $400 to $2,000. The nine units shown total $4,800 at Totem, 71 Franklin Street (Broadway); www.totemdesign.com.

2. Ladislav Czernek's Rack and Pinion shelving system is made of maple or mahogany shelves hinged together and supported by ebonized mahogany wall brackets. The configuration shown costs $2,600 and can be ordered from Epoche Studios, 397 Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

3. Plinto, an Italian system by Former, has cabinets and shelves attached to a lacquered wall panel, and a walnut credenza with drawers. Combinations start at $3,900 at M2L, 979 Third Avenue (to the trade).

4. A stackable cupboard system called Piroscafo would be at home in a library, dining room, even a kitchen. The aluminum frame can be laminated with cherry wood or lacquered in white, blue, green or black. The three-tiered lacquered version shown, 95 by 88 inches, is $7,744 at Format, 50 Wooster Street (Broome Street).

5. The Tonic grid system by Offi can be customized with drawers, doors and even a desk-table that attaches to the grid to create a work space or dining area. The system comes in walnut or maple; the model shown, 63 inches high, 63 inches wide and 15 inches deep, costs $2,299 in walnut and $1,999 in maple. For store locations: (800) 383-6334 or www.offi.com.

6. Listen up, nomads. The Rakks system consists of floor-to-ceiling poles anchored by tension, not screws, and brackets that can be installed without tools. An 8-foot pole is $70; a 9-foot pole is $75; 8-inch brackets are $11 a pair, and a 16-inch pair is $24. You supply your own shelves. The system is available at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street).
7. Translucent Plexiglas doors sit in the vinyl-covered plywood frame of the Cell Tower by G7, 67 inches high by 36 inches wide; $4,500 at Totem.

8. Piero Lissoni's plastic containers, 15 inches high, 15 inches deep and 30 inches long, come with or without doors and wheels. Units stack or can be arranged to form a low credenza. In orange, green, blue, black and clear; units are $377 each with doors and wheels, $306 without, at Kartell, 45 Greene Street (Broome Street).
